items.content:
The learning goals of this paragraph are as follows:

- You can explain the importance of the steam engine during the Industrial Revolution

- You can explain the connection between modern imperialism and raw materials

- You can explain what a transport revolution is

Even before the French Revolution in France, England had its Industrial Revolution. It was of a different kind. In England, agricultural machines on large fields had already started to produce more food. This caused the population to grow. In addition to food, they also needed stuff. There was especially a high demand for clothing. Before the Industrial Revolution, everything was made by hand. That took a lot of time. To make more and faster stuff, the newly invented steam engine was placed in factories. Steam engines operated on steam from heated water boilers.

A lot of coal was needed to light the fires. That is why there was a lot of demand for coal. The demand for coal led to a lot of mining in England.

prompt.body: Explain, in your own words, what a revolution is.

values.value:
A revolution is a very important change in a short period of time in the way that people do things. Examples of revolutions are:

- The American revolution

- The French revolution

- The agricultural revolution

- The industrial revolution

content.body:
A revolution is a very important change in a short period of time in the way that people do things. Examples of revolutions are:

- The American revolution

- The French revolution

- The agricultural revolution

- The industrial revolution

prompt.body: Why were many mines opened during the Industrial revolution?

values.value: Steam engines operated on steam from heated water boilers. A lot of coal was needed to light the fires. Therefore, coal was in high demand. The demand for coal led to a lot of mining in England.

content.body: Steam engines operated on steam from heated water boilers. A lot of coal was needed to light the fires. Therefore, coal was in high demand. The demand for coal led to a lot of mining in England.

items.content: In addition to coal from mining, raw materials were also needed to make something. Many of those raw materials came from the colonies. So existing colonies were enlarged, and new territories conquered. Europe's influence on the colonies also increased. All this is called modern imperialism. European factories made products from colonial raw materials. These were intended for their own population and the European market. Surplus was also sold in the colonies. In this way, colonies became a market as well as a raw material supplier for Europe.

prompt.body: Explain, in your own words, the meaning of Imperialism

values.value: Imperialism: a situation in which one country has a lot of power or influence over others, especially in political and economic matters:

content.body: Imperialism: a situation in which one country has a lot of power or influence over others, especially in political and economic matters:

prompt.body: Indicate which characteristics belong to modern imperialism. There are several correct answers.

content.body: New colonies were conquered.
It existed from about 1750 to 1820.
Power over existing colonies was expanded.
The local population was allowed to rule the colonies.
Colonies were needed for raw materials.
In this time colonies were viewed necessary for it's materials. However, looking back we can realize that trade would have made those materials possible as well.
Many factories were built in the colonies.
It existed from around 1850 untill 1920.
In Europe, products were produced that were also sold in the colonies

items.content:
You can recognize factories that were built after the industrial revolution by their high chimneys. Before the Industrial Revolution factories did not have chimneys because they did not use steam engines. Back then, workshops often had a water wheel to set machines in motion.

Old workshops had small windows, but it was only later thought that it was nice for the workers to work with lots of light. Many factories were on the water. This was the fastest way to supply raw materials and transport manufactured products. For a long time, there were not enough railways in the Netherlands to do this. This ship did not run on steam power but on wind power - just look at the masts.

prompt.body: Explain why factories were often built near water before the Industrial Revolution.

values.value:
Before the Industrial Revolution, workshops often had a water wheel. This water wheel was turned by the water of a well-flowing brook or river. The waterwheel could then set a simple machine (a large sawing machine in a sawmill, for example) in motion.

Also, ships were often used for transporting material to and product from the factory.

content.body:
Before the Industrial Revolution, workshops often had a water wheel. This water wheel was turned by the water of a well-flowing brook or river. The waterwheel could then set a simple machine (a large sawing machine in a sawmill, for example) in motion.

Also, ships were often used for transporting material to and product from the factory.

prompt.body: Explain why factories weren't necessarily built on the water after the Industrial Revolution.

values.value: After the Industrial Revolution, factories used steam engines to power machines. A steam engine didn't need water to run - just water to fill its boiler. A new factory therefore did not necessarily have to be built on the water, although that was also easy to keep refilling the boiler. And for the possible supply of coal from far away, of course.

content.body: After the Industrial Revolution, factories used steam engines to power machines. A steam engine didn't need water to run - just water to fill its boiler. A new factory therefore did not necessarily have to be built on the water, although that was also easy to keep refilling the boiler. And for the possible supply of coal from far away, of course.

prompt.body: Put the following developments in the correct (chronological) order.

content.body: They couldn't make enough things by hand, so the steam engine was invented.
New agricultural machines were developed.
These machines ensured that more food could be produced.
The larger population also needed more stuff.
In factories, products were massively produced
Well done, this is the correct order!
You almost had it, try again!

values.value: ec46da4638d1a6bc9c7d601efcb88bd2

items.content: England was early with industrialization. The rest of Europe followed later. For example, the first steam-powered factory in the Netherlands was not built until 1830. The Netherlands lagged somewhat behind in industrialization. In 1851 there were only about 300 steam engines in factories here. The first railway in the Netherlands - from Amsterdam to Haarlem - was opened in 1839. With a steam locomotive, the journey took only half an hour. Many people did not dare to join, afraid of the 'enormous speed' of the new means of transport.

items.altText: Image from 1720 - Before the Industrial Revolution, people traveled on foot, on horseback or in a tow barge. You see such a barge here. The boat is pulled over the water by the horse on the left. You can imagine that this was not a fast mode of transport.

prompt.body: Where did the industrial revolution start?

content.body: The Netherlands
France
England
The United States

prompt.body: In your own words, describe what Industrialization means

values.value: Industrialization is the process by which an economy is transformed from a primarily agricultural one to one based on the manufacturing of goods. Individual manual labor is often replaced by mechanized mass production, and craftsmen are replaced by assembly lines. Characteristics of industrialization include economic growth, the more efficient division of labor, and the use of technological innovation to solve problems as opposed to dependency on conditions outside of human control.

content.body: Industrialization is the process by which an economy is transformed from a primarily agricultural one to one based on the manufacturing of goods. Individual manual labor is often replaced by mechanized mass production, and craftsmen are replaced by assembly lines. Characteristics of industrialization include economic growth, the more efficient division of labor, and the use of technological innovation to solve problems as opposed to dependency on conditions outside of human control.

prompt.body: Explain why some people were afraid to travel with the train at first.

values.value: People were not used to the speed that the train could go and were woried that the the speed would be harmful to a persons health.

content.body: People were not used to the speed that the train could go and were woried that the the speed would be harmful to a persons health.

prompt.body: Which was the first train route in the Netherlands?

content.body: Amsterdam - Haarlem
Amsterdam - Den Haag
Amsterdam - Utrecht
Amsterdam - Eindhoven

prompt.body: Why do you think that Amsterdam had to be accesible by train?

values.value: Amsterdam was the capital of the Netherlands

content.body: Amsterdam was the capital of the Netherlands

items.content: From about 1860 onwards, a lot of money was spent on the industrialization of the Netherlands. The required coal for the steam engines came from South Limburg. At that time, their transport was already going by train and by ship through new canals. An important consequence of the Industrial Revolution was a transport revolution. Suddenly it was possible to travel throughout the Netherlands without having to spend weeks on it.

prompt.body: To what did the government invest the most money to from 1861 onwards, and why?

values.value: Most of the money was spent on the construction of railways and canals. More steam engines were needed for industrialization. The coal for the steam engines had to come from South Limburg. This was very far away from the big cities. So investments had to be made in modern means of transport in order to be able to industrialize properly.

content.body: Most of the money was spent on the construction of railways and canals. More steam engines were needed for industrialization. The coal for the steam engines had to come from South Limburg. This was very far away from the big cities. So investments had to be made in modern means of transport in order to be able to industrialize properly.

prompt.body: Explain why King William I became king of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands in 1815.

values.value: William I was the official (family) successor of the old Stadtholder Willem V. He had fled to England when the Netherlands was taken by the French. So when the English were looking for someone to become king of the new kingdom on the northern border of defeated France from Napoleon, they quickly found this Orange.

content.body: William I was the official (family) successor of the old Stadtholder Willem V. He had fled to England when the Netherlands was taken by the French. So when the English were looking for someone to become king of the new kingdom on the northern border of defeated France from Napoleon, they quickly found this Orange.

prompt.body:
Statement: the Industrial revolution was not a revolution.

Give an argument for and an argument against this statement.

values.value:
For:

The Industrial Revolution was not a real revolution, because the changes took place over a very long time. So it was not a rapid change and that is a hallmark of a real revolution.

 

Against:

The Industrial Revolution was a real revolution, because the changes were very big. The whole of society changed thanks to the Industrial Revolution. A big change is also a mark of a real revolution.

content.body:
For:

The Industrial Revolution was not a real revolution, because the changes took place over a very long time. So it was not a rapid change and that is a hallmark of a real revolution.

Against:

The Industrial Revolution was a real revolution, because the changes were very big. The whole of society changed thanks to the Industrial Revolution. A big change is also a mark of a real revolution.

prompt.body:
Imagine you are a comtemporary and you witnessed the first train ride in the Netherlands.

Investigate the reactions of different contemporaries. Do this by sending a letter to a newspaper yourself. Your letter sent in must meet the following requirements:

- at the top are a place and a date with year.

- you briefly describe who you are.

- you describe how you experienced the train: you can choose whether you were on board the train or stood along the track. you can choose whether you are positive or negative about the train.

- you explain what you think the future of this means of transport is.

values.value: Personal answer.

content.body: Personal answer.

prompt.body: Put the following events in the correct order

content.body: Belgian revolution which leads to the Belgian independence from the Netherlands
William III crowned king of the Netherlands
The childrens law of Van Houten prohibits children up to the age of 12 to work
James Watt improves the steam engine
William II crowned king of the Netherlands
Robert Morse makes first electric telegraph
Constitutional revision
Aletta Jacobs becomes the first woman in the Netherlands to complete university
The battle of Waterloo
The first steam train in the Netherlands
First successful steamship

1878 Aletta Jacobs becomes the first woman in the Netherlands to complete university

content.body: Napoleon
the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Hanover, Brunswick, and Nassau
Russia
The United States, The United Kingdom and France

prompt.body: What happened to the Netherlands after the battle of Waterloo?

values.value: After the 1815, the United Kingdom of the Netherlands consisted of the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg with William the 1st as king.

content.body: After the 1815, the United Kingdom of the Netherlands consisted of the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg with William the 1st as king.

prompt.body: What was the reason that Belgium stood up against the regime of the Netherlands?

values.value: The main reason for the Belgian revolt was the control that the Netherlands had over economic, social and political aspects. They lacked general autonomy and there was a difference of religion, where the Netherlands was mainly protestant, Belgium was mostly catholic.

content.body: The main reason for the Belgian revolt was the control that the Netherlands had over economic, social and political aspects. They lacked general autonomy and there was a difference of religion, where the Netherlands was mainly protestant, Belgium was mostly catholic.

prompt.body: Who was king during the constitutional revision of 1848?

values.value: King William II

content.body: King William II

items.content:
Factory workers worked up to 16 hours a day, six days a week. In the factories it was very noisy because of the machines. It was dark and accidents happened. In any case, it was unhealthy to work in a factory. But not only the working conditions were bad.
Because so many farm workers worked in the cities, wages were low. And because so many people were looking for shelter, there weren't enough houses. Cities were unprepared for the arrival of so many workers and quickly built working-class neighborhoods. Several families had to live in one small and often bad house.

Both in the country and in the city, the whole family worked together. This meant that parents and (almost) all children worked in factories. The children were sometimes only five years old when they started. This child labor was good for the factory owners. Little children's fingers could reach everything and were very cheap. Children often work as long as their parents and for even lower wages! They didn't go to school, because that was too expensive: that wouldn't contribute to the family income.

prompt.body: Name three working conditions that were bad

values.value: in the factories there was a lot of noise from all the machines. in addition, it was dark and no extra attention was paid to safety. accidents often happened in the factories. It was also very unhealthy to work in the factory due to (fine) dust and poor ventilation.

content.body: in the factories there was a lot of noise from all the machines. in addition, it was dark and no extra attention was paid to safety. accidents often happened in the factories. It was also very unhealthy to work in the factory due to (fine) dust and poor ventilation.

prompt.body: Explain why the living conditions were poor in the working-class districts

values.value: Several families lived in one small and often unsafe house. The districts were not cleaned and were therefore very filthy. There was also little daylight in the workers' houses.

content.body: Several families lived in one small and often unsafe house. The districts were not cleaned and were therefore very filthy. There was also little daylight in the workers' houses.

items.content:
Around 1860 there was organized resistance against the poor working and living conditions of the workers and child labour. Many workers wanted concrete improvement of their situation. That is why they united in labor unions. They negotiated with the factory bosses and they organized strikes when workers and employers disagreed. Later, people from the government and parliament also concerned themselves with the situation of the workers and their children. They collectively called all the problems the social queston. Books, poems and newspapers also paid attention to this.

In 1874 the first social law was passed: the Van Houten Children's Act. This law meant that children were not allowed to work in a factory until they were twelve. The Compulsory Education Act of 1901 obliged children between the ages of six and twelve to attend school. Many factory owners agreed to the social laws. They also realized that sick, dissatisfied workers were more expensive than healthy, satisfied workers. Thus, the conditions for the workers and their families gradually improved. There were many more social laws. This provided for the following:

- Shorter working days and higher wages followed.
- Safety laws were in place in the factories.
- Benefits were provided for people who became unemployed or incapacitated for work.
- Housing laws were enacted, which meant that better workers' houses were built.
- Underground sewers replaced the above-ground sewers.

prompt.body: Why were strikes an important tool for labor unions?

values.value: During a strike, workers stop working. They do this to force the factory owner to do something. It cannot produce anything if no one is working. So a union can use a strike to put pressure on a factory owner

content.body: During a strike, workers stop working. They do this to force the factory owner to do something. It cannot produce anything if no one is working. So a union can use a strike to put pressure on a factory owner

prompt.body: Social laws as a whole brought about many changes. Name at least three of these changes.

values.value:
• the working days became shorter.
  • it became safer to work in factories.
  • there were no longer any (young) children working in factories.
  • more children went to school.
  • the unemployed and the disabled received a benefit as a small income.
  • workers' houses and neighborhoods were built.
  • underground sewers were built instead of above ground.
  • more schools came.
  • ordinary people got more free time.

content.body:
• the working days became shorter.
  • it became safer to work in factories.
  • there were no longer any (young) children working in factories.
  • more children went to school.
  • the unemployed and the disabled received a benefit as a small income.
  • workers' houses and neighborhoods were built.
  • underground sewers were built instead of above ground.
  • more schools came.
  • ordinary people got more free time.

prompt.body:
View the image and read the text. Then explain what you think the cartoon is about.

"You're right, Mr Aalberse, I don't belong in the factory. But if I stay at home and cannot earn money, may I send my children to eat with you?"

values.value: This cartoon is about the fact that the whole family had to work. Mother would take the children to the factory to work and take care of them. If she did not do this, a family would not have enough income. The ban on child labor was therefore not welcomed by everyone.

content.body: This cartoon is about the fact that the whole family had to work. Mother would take the children to the factory to work and take care of them. If she did not do this, a family would not have enough income. The ban on child labor was therefore not welcomed by everyone.

prompt.body:
View the image and read the text. Then explain what you think the cartoon is about.

"A factory owner in Krommenie does not allow workers to join a union."

values.value: This cartoon is about unions. Unions fought for better conditions for the workers. Factory owners were against this, because they believed that only they should determine wages and working hours.

content.body: This cartoon is about unions. Unions fought for better conditions for the workers. Factory owners were against this, because they believed that only they should determine wages and working hours.
